bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 15, 1941

div1.p: Hench thanks Kellogg for the reaction letters, from both Cubans and Americans, to the painting. He discusses the sentiments in these letters.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, August 15, 1941
div1.opener:
August 15, 1941
Mr. George A. Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
Thank you very kindly for the letters giving
the reactions to the painting. They are as one would ex-
pect. The Americans like it very much, the Cubans don't.
I suspect that the Cubans would be very satisfied with the
Cuban version, probably framed. Even though it is rather
sketchy it is no more sketchy than many modern paintings,
and it would appeal to their pride so much that they would
forget any artistic deficiencies which Mr. Cornwell might
see in it.

It is very helpful to me to get these letters as
it will help to govern my future contacts and remarks to
the Cubans when I visit them again.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
